content.text: A function is a block of reusable code that only runs when it is called. You can pass data (known as parameters) into a function, and a function can return a result.
Functions help you avoid repetition, make code more organized, and allow easier debugging.
def keyword
In Python, you define a function using the def keyword:

def my_function():
    print("Hello from a function")
You call a function by using its name followed by parentheses:

def my_function():
    print("Hello from a function")

my_function()

# Output:
# Hello from a function
Practice 1:

content.text: Function Parameters
Information can be passed into functions as parameters. Parameters act as variables inside the function.
Note: A function can have multiple parameters, separated by commas.

def greet(name):
    print("Hello", name)

greet("Alice")
greet("Bob")

# Output:
# Hello Alice
# Hello Bob
Number of Arguments: When calling a function, you must provide the exact number of arguments it expects.

def add(x, y):
    print(x + y)

add(5, 7)    # Correct

# Output:
# 12
Default Parameter Value: You can assign a default value to a parameter. If the caller does not provide it, the default will be used.

def greet(name="Student"):
    print("Hello", name)

greet("Alice")
greet()

# Output:
# Hello Alice
# Hello Student
Keyword Arguments : You can also pass arguments by name (keywords). The order then does not matter.

def student_info(name, age):
    print(name, "is", age, "years old")

student_info(age=20, name="Alice")

# Output:
# Alice is 20 years old
Practice 1:

content.text: Practice 2:
Write a function personal_greeting(name, city) that prints a personalized greeting.

items: Create a function named personal_greeting(name, city) that:
Accepts two parameters: a person’s name and the city they live in.
Prints a sentence like: "Hi Alice, how is the weather in New York?".
Call the function at least twice with different names and cities.

content.starter_code:
# Write a function that takes name and city as parameters
# def personal_greeting(name, city):
#     Your code here

# Test your function with two different calls
# personal_greeting("Alice", "New York")

content.expected_output:

content.solution:
def personal_greeting(name, city):

personal_greeting("Bob", "Chicago")

Make sure to call the function twice with different arguments
Remember to include the print() statement inside the function

content.text: Arbitrary Arguments (*args) :
If you don’t know how many arguments will be passed, use *args. Inside the function, args is treated as a tuple.

def total(*numbers):
    print(sum(numbers))

total(5, 10, 15)

# Output:
# 30
Arbitrary Keyword Arguments (**kwargs)
If you don’t know how many keyword arguments will be passed, use **kwargs. Inside the function, kwargs is treated as a dictionary.

def student(**info):
    print("Name:", info["name"])
    print("Age:", info["age"])

student(name="Alice", age=21)

# Output:
# Name: Alice
# Age: 21
Practice 1:
Write a function print_friends(*friends) that:

items: Accepts any number of names.
Prints them all in a single line, separated by commas.
Test it with 3 and then 5 names.

content.starter_code:
# Write a function that accepts any number of friend names
# def print_friends(*friends):
#     Your code here

# Test with 3 names
# print_friends("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie")

# Test with 5 names
# print_friends("Tom", "Jerry", "Mickey", "Minnie", "Donald")
content.expected_output:
My friends are: Alice, Bob, Charlie
My friends are: Tom, Jerry, Mickey, Minnie, Donald
content.solution:
def print_friends(*friends):
    print("My friends are:", ", ".join(friends))

print_friends("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie")
print_friends("Tom", "Jerry", "Mickey", "Minnie", "Donald")
hints: Use *friends to accept any number of arguments
Use ', '.join(friends) to combine all names with commas
Test the function with both 3 and 5 names as requested

content.text: Practice 2:
Create a function named employee(**data) that uses arbitrary keyword arguments.
Your function should:

items: Accept employee details as keyword arguments. At a minimum, expect three fields:
Print a single formatted sentence in this style:
After defining the function, call it at least once with all three keyword arguments (e.g., employee(name="Alice", role="Engineer", salary=70000)).

content.text:
"name" (string) → employee’s name
"role" (string) → employee’s job role
"salary" (integer or float) → employee’s yearly salary
Name: Alice, Role: Engineer, Salary: 70000

content.starter_code:
# Write a function that accepts employee data as keyword arguments
# def employee(**data):
#     Your code here

# Test your function
# employee(name="Alice", role="Engineer", salary=70000)
content.solution:
def employee(**data):
    print(f"Name: {data['name']}, Role: {data['role']}, Salary: {data['salary']}")

# Example calls
employee(name="Alice", role="Engineer", salary=70000)
hints: Use **data to accept any number of keyword arguments
Access dictionary values using data['name'], data['role'], data['salary']
Use f-string formatting to create the output sentence

content.text: Return Values
A function can return a value using the return statement.
Tip: Returning is different from printing. Printing shows output on the screen, while returning gives you a value to use later.

def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(5, 7)
print(result)

# Output:
# 12

content.text:
Functions are one of the most important building blocks in Python.
They let us group reusable code, make programs easier to read, and reduce mistakes by avoiding repetition.
Key Points

items:
Defining a Function
  • Use the def keyword followed by the function name and parentheses.
  • Example:
    def my_function():
    print("Hello")

Calling a Function
  • Execute the function by writing its name followed by ().
  • Example:
    my_function()

Parameters and Arguments
  • Parameters are placeholders in the function definition.
  • Arguments are the actual values you pass when calling.

Default Parameters
  • You can give parameters default values so they are optional.
  • ⚠️ Avoid using mutable objects (lists, dicts) as defaults.

Keyword Arguments
  • Specify arguments by name, not just position.
  • This makes calls more readable and flexible.

Arbitrary Arguments
  • *args lets you pass many positional arguments (tuple).
  • **kwargs lets you pass many keyword arguments (dictionary).

Return Values
  • Functions can return values using the return keyword.
  • Without return, a function gives back None.

Recursion
  • A function can call itself.
  • Always include a base case to stop recursion.
  • Python has a recursion depth limit.

Best Practices
  • Keep functions small and focused on one task.
  • Use descriptive names.
  • Document with docstrings.
  • Avoid unexpected side effects.
  • Test with different inputs, including edge cases.

content.text: Why Functions Matter

items: They make programs modular: easier to understand, test, and maintain.
They allow code reuse, saving time and effort.
They support abstraction, letting you hide complexity behind a simple interface.

content.text: ✅ Next Step for Students

items: Practice by writing small utility functions (calculators, converters, string formatters).
Try combining different parameter types (*args, **kwargs, defaults) in one function.
Challenge yourself with recursive problems (factorial, Fibonacci, sum of a list).
